articles.headline: The Mideast War Threatens Harris in Michigan as Arab Voters Reject Her
articles.snippet: A year after the Oct. 7 attacks, Kamala Harris faces deepening Democratic fractures in a crucial state. Interviews suggest that her support from Muslim and Arab Americans is drying up.
articles.abstract: A year after the Oct. 7 attacks, Kamala Harris faces deepening Democratic fractures in a crucial state. Interviews suggest that her support from Muslim and Arab Americans is drying up.
articles.lead_paragraph: One year after the deadliest day for Jews since the Holocaust, the relentless and escalating violence in the Middle East is threatening the Democratic coalition in the United States. Arab American voters show signs of abandoning the Democratic ticket, while some Jews worry about their future in a party their families embraced for generations.

articles.headline: Washington Worries the Israelis Will Bomb Iran’s Nuclear Sites. But Can They?
articles.snippet: For 22 years, Israeli forces have planned for this moment. But it seems unlikely that they will strike Iran’s nuclear facilities in the next round of retaliation, or that they would be successful without American help.
articles.abstract: For 22 years, Israeli forces have planned for this moment. But it seems unlikely that they will strike Iran’s nuclear facilities in the next round of retaliation, or that they would be successful without American help.
articles.lead_paragraph: Two years ago, dozens of Israeli fighter jets roared over the Mediterranean Sea, simulating a strike on Iran’s nuclear facilities, a drill the Israeli defense forces openly advertised as an exercise in “long-range flight, aerial refueling and striking distant targets.”
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger, Eric Schmitt and Ronen Bergman

articles.headline: China’s Policy Reversal Sparks ‘Mind Boggling’ Stock Rally
articles.snippet: The government has fired up investors by encouraging banks to lend more to buyers of stocks and real estate, but officials refrained on Tuesday from promising more stimulus.
articles.abstract: The government has fired up investors by encouraging banks to lend more to buyers of stocks and real estate, but officials refrained on Tuesday from promising more stimulus.
articles.lead_paragraph: Just a few weeks ago, many investors in China’s stock markets were ready to give up and eager to sell. Then late last month, traders rushed in to make bullish bets after the government’s leaders announced a series of steps to stimulate China’s faltering economy.
articles.byline: By Keith Bradsher, Chris Buckley and Meaghan Tobin

articles.headline: As Hurricanes Strike, Insurance Costs Soar for Commercial Real Estate
articles.snippet: Struggling landlords and developers are seeking leeway on coverage from their lenders — mostly in vain.
articles.abstract: Struggling landlords and developers are seeking leeway on coverage from their lenders — mostly in vain.
articles.lead_paragraph: Postpandemic vacancies and surging debt payments have eaten away at commercial real estate for more than two years. Even as those threats start to fade, owners of strip malls, apartment buildings and office towers face a problem that could last much longer: soaring insurance costs.

articles.headline: Poll Finds Harris Rising as She Challenges Trump on Change
articles.snippet: A national Times/Siena poll found Kamala Harris with a slim lead over Donald J. Trump. Voters were more likely to see her, not Mr. Trump, as a break from the status quo.
articles.abstract: A national Times/Siena poll found Kamala Harris with a slim lead over Donald J. Trump. Voters were more likely to see her, not Mr. Trump, as a break from the status quo.
articles.lead_paragraph: Follow along with the latest updates on Trump, Harris and the 2024 election.
articles.byline: By Adam Nagourney, Ruth Igielnik and Camille Baker

articles.headline: A U.N. Official’s Payments: Zero Interest Loans, a Mercedes and a Tennis Sponsorship
articles.snippet: The official secretly took $3 million in gifts from a businessman to whom he steered the organization’s funds, a court ruled. The U.N. got a song about the ocean.
articles.abstract: The official secretly took $3 million in gifts from a businessman to whom he steered the organization’s funds, a court ruled. The U.N. got a song about the ocean.
articles.lead_paragraph: A high-ranking United Nations official secretly took $3 million in gifts from a British businessman while he steered more than $58 million of the organization’s money to the man’s companies, according to a ruling from an internal U.N. court.
articles.byline: By David A. Fahrenthold and Farnaz Fassihi

articles.headline: TikTok Faces Barrage of Lawsuits Around Teens and Mental Health
articles.snippet: More than a dozen states sued TikTok on Tuesday for creating an app designed to be addictive to children and teenagers.
articles.abstract: More than a dozen states sued TikTok on Tuesday for creating an app designed to be addictive to children and teenagers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Thirteen states and the District of Columbia sued TikTok on Tuesday, accusing the company of creating an intentionally addictive app that harmed children and teenagers while making false claims to the public about its commitment to safety.
articles.byline: By Sapna Maheshwari and David McCabe
